posts.title: Pharmacokinetics and Toxicity
posts.text: Deep-PK: A web-server for pharmacokinetics and toxicity screening, interpretation and optimization. Be aware of: The 73 pharmacokinetics and toxicity models each have their own chemical space of training molecules. Thus, the confidence for distant or unique query molecules can be low. Take a look of model’s performance and confidence levels in result page. What’s the advantages of using Deep-PK? Better performance and easier to use than other available tools

posts.title: Antibody Engineering
posts.text: CSM-AB: A web-server for accurate antibody-antigen binding affinity (KD, ∆G) predictions. Be aware of: This web-server does not do anything with “Docking” but single point energy calcualtion; thus, users should provide their query antibody-antigen complexes to get their binding affinity predictions done. Binding affinity, KD (Dissociation Constant), represents how strong the antibody or antigen binds to its partner. In this study, we simply used ∆G for “binding energy”. What’s the advantages of using CSM-AB? Better performance and easier to use than other available tools Very fast and efficiently re-rank the docked ab-ag complexes mCSM-AB2 and mmCSM-AB: Predicting the changes of antibody-antigen binding affinity (∆KD, ∆∆G) upon single point mutation (mCSM-AB2) and multiple mutations (mmCSM-AB) Be aware of: Binding affinity, KD (Dissociation Constant), represents how strong the antibody or antigen binds to its partner. In this study, we simply used ∆∆G for the changes of “binding energy” upon mutation. The negative ∆∆G represents decreasing of ab-ag binding affinity and vice versa. This is opposite to the conventional sign of ∆∆G because we calculated the labels (∆∆G) by ∆G(WT) - ∆G(MT). What’s the advantages of using mCSM-AB2 and mmCSM-AB? Better performance and easier to use than other available tools Very fast and efficiently browse hotspots or meaningful mutations via Alanine Scanning or Saturation Mutagenesis.

pages.title: Who am I
pages.text: I’m a Bioinformatician, Biochemist, and computer enthusiast with a passion for unraveling biological mysteries through computational methods. Throughout my Bachelor’s Degree, my focus was on conducting in vitro experiments predominantly rooted in molecular biology. I delved into tasks like screening anti-cancer or anti-inflammatory molecules across various cell lines using techniques such as Western blotting. Working within the dynamic environment of the “Free Radical” laboratory, I had the opportunity to broaden my skill set, engaging in biophysical experiments and utilizing diverse instruments like UV/VIS spectrometers and Rahman microscopy. In the realm of cell-related assays like Western blotting, achieving reproducibility is paramount yet often challenging. It’s not merely about mastering techniques; numerous unknown variables can affect outcomes. A memorable insight came from a colleague likening it to the uniqueness of bodily functions despite identical diets—an analogy that underscored the complexity of the task. My epiphany came during a Biophysical Chemistry class when Professor Han introduced Molecular Docking and Molecular Dynamics Simulations. Unlike experimental work, these computational methods offered a promise of perfect reproducibility. That pivotal moment cemented my decision to chart a path in Computational Biology. Furthermore, since I was young, I’ve had a pure enjoyment for fixing, modifying, and building computers. This passion positioned me perfectly to delve into Computational Biology. As evident from my CV, I’ve explored a diverse array of projects, extending beyond the conventional scope. These include: Screening anti-malodor materials from natural compounds: Utilizing “Gas Cylinder” detectors to measure malodor agents. Investigating methods to reduce the toxicity and pungency of pharmaceutical and coloring agents. Conducting assessments of physical properties such as melting point and evaluating the anti-cancer efficacy of PNAs. Employing Molecular Docking simulations to discern the differential interactions among major anti-neuraminidase inhibitors.
